items.content_html: After this today‚Äôs meeting, my database project has become 10 times larger but 25% simpler. I hope I can still meet my deadline.
My work day started off far more slowly than expected. Therefore, I‚Äôm coding‚Äîmaybe all day‚Äîfor my ‚Äúnumber 3‚Äù project.

I took my (old) Sony RX 100 camera to the splash park to take pictures of the kids and got dozens of great shots. My wife and I looked back at our kids‚Äô baby pictures a little, after looking through today‚Äôs photos, and had a great time doing so tonight.
I beat Bastion tonight. What a great ending. I may do the second playthrough, New Game+, though I may take a break beforehand.
I‚Äôm looking forward to a visit with the family to the county fair tonight. Last year‚Äôs fair was a lot of fun.

I have been seriously considering holding on to my iPhone 7 Plus for a third year. I just got a new screen and a new battery, It looks almost brand new, I still like the camera, I never complain about it being slow, and iOS 12 promises to improve performance when I upgrade to it. I feel the same way about my Series 1 Apple Watch, too, though my desire to upgrade it to whatever model Apple releases next is still a lot higher.
Bastion is so much fun that I bought the developer‚Äôs subsequent game, Transistor.

I spent most of the day coding an Access app for work. I‚Äôm coding VBA now almost like it‚Äôs a proper object-oriented language: lots of tiny classes that do one thing only, basically no repeated code segments, use of design patterns wherever possible, and so on.
I‚Äôm enjoying this week‚Äôs Accidental Tech Podcast.
Blog post: SwiftoDo Development Notes, July 2018

items.title: Introducing my latest iOS app: Simple Call Blocker
items.content_html:
Simple Call Blocker is a free app for blocking unwanted calls on iOS.

It provides a basic way to block lots of numbers via a CallKit directory extension‚Äìwhich is great for blocking neighbor spam.

Unlike almost every other call blocker out there, mine is completely free and doesn‚Äôt need access to your contacts to work.

Try it out. It‚Äôs free.

If you want to know more, there‚Äôs a website with screenshots and a FAQ. I wrote a blog post describing my motivation for writing it, too.
I replaced my old, crumbling, extra- extra large Grifiti wrist rest with a new one, suitably sized for my tenkeyless keyboard. It was a good move.
üéµ Tonight I‚Äôm working overtime and listening to The Hold Steady, which almost makes it all right.
Vacation is wonderful, but boy does it feel like a due date for everything that‚Äôs open at work.

I left my iPhone at the Apple Store for a screen repair and a new battery. I‚Äôm using my Essential Phone as an actual phone for the first time this afternoon. I do not plan to write a ‚Äúswitching post‚Äù though‚Äîit‚Äôs just temporary. üòÄ

items.title: I find myself shifting my listening time away from podcasts and more toward music lately
items.content_html:
I started listening to podcasts in 2008. I think, now, I am, for the first time, burnt out on the medium. I listen to a lot of podcasts while I work, but lately I‚Äôve found I can barely remember what the episodes were about shortly after they finish. I think I am tuning them out.

I am paring back my subscriptions down‚Äîway down‚Äîto a few favorites and listening to more music instead. It‚Äôs symmetrical to how I got into podcast listening: I was burnt out on listening to music all day long, and became uninterested in music for several years.
Hot take: The 12.9‚Äù iPad Pro I‚Äôm working on right now is not large enough!
Blog post: On Internet Trolls

üéµ I‚Äôm back to my wired OPPO PM-3 & HA-2 SE headphones stack today, listening to Foreverland, by The Divine Comedy. It‚Äôs an album that slipped by me in 2016. I used to love The Divine Comedy in the late 1990s, and still take Casanova for a spin every six months or so.

items.title: Trial runs for fascism are in full flow
items.content_html:
This article by Fintan O‚ÄôToole in The Irish Times is a few weeks old now, but I keep thinking about it.

Fascism doesn‚Äôt arise suddenly in an existing democracy. It is not easy to get people to give up their ideas of freedom and civility. You have to do trial runs that, if they are done well, serve two purposes. They get people used to something they may initially recoil from; and they allow you to refine and calibrate. This is what is happening now and we would be fools not to see it.

Mr. O‚ÄôToole lays out a simple and convincing argument outlining ideas that I have been mulling over in my head, but not writing much about, since Trump‚Äôs election on November 8, 2016. What has happened‚Äîat an accelerating pace, I think, since last year‚Äîis that the bounds of what is considered normal have been stretched so far into what was previously outrageous that I fear there is no going back. If Trump and the Republican Party are proving that the U.S. president is above the law, and that much of what governed the government was merely tradition, which is disposable for political expediency, then what, if anything, will constrain the power and the actions of future U.S. presidents?
Oh! I‚Äôm getting a Microsoft Office update this morning. I wonder what office suites were like in the year 2016‚Ä¶
I have pared back my Twitter following list to Lin-Manuel Miranda and Ole Begemann, which is sometimes weird and sometimes delightful, the few moments per week I check in on them.

I‚Äôm super pleased listening to these V-Moda Crossfade 2 Codex Edition headphones all day at work, over Bluetooth. (Wireless use is pretty rare for me.) Great sound. Great isolation. The top of my head is a little sore from the headband, though. (They are kind of heavy.) üéß

I checked out the new MacBook Pros at the Apple Store. The new keyboard looks (feels) like a winner to me. It is quieter, and there‚Äôs a good chance it won‚Äôt have the same reliability problem as the prior generation. I would prefer a 15‚Äù one without the TouchBar, though, but don‚Äôt plan to buy one until my 2015 rMBP breaks or is no longer supported.

Our appointment for family photos at the park got canceled today due to heavy rain. We ended up shopping and eating pancakes instead. Not a bad trade-off for the day, but I would have liked to have the photos later.
